Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Atomic High Magnetic Field Probe
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is focused on developing a new probe technology for high magnetic field sensing and measurement. The technology utilizes a circuit-free, atom-based field sensing element that affords absolute measurements of strong fields with high-speed all-optical readout that is free of electromagnetic interference, directly addressing capability gaps in existing technologies relevant to a variety of industries. A broad commercial potential is in fault-detection in condition-monitoring systems for motors and generators, where faults due to occurrences such as over-fluxing or magnetization can lead to major damage, costly repairs and production downtime. The atomic probe addresses an unmet need for reliable, localized measurements up to several Tesla of magnetic field within and surrounding conductive components in rotating machines for early fault detection. The technology also promises to expand capabilities of laboratory measurement instrumentation and contribute to experimental high magnetic field science requiring advanced instrumentation for measurement in the 1 to 100 Tesla range. The extraordinary opportunities for scientific research and technological development represented by investment in high magnetic field laboratories were set out in influential reports of the National Academies of Science (2004 and 2013). The field probe is expected to contribute to this on-going, multi-disciplinary effort.

The intellectual merit of this project includes the research and demonstration of key components and capabilities of an atomic high magnetic field probe. The innovation lies in a fundamentally new measurement approach that provides robust, absolute-standard (atomic) measurement and sensing of magnetic fields up to tens of Tesla at high speed and precision with a compact, circuit-free, all-optical sensing element. The probe operates based on atomic physics principles that describe the spectroscopic response of atoms in strong magnetic fields, and quantum-optics phenomena that serve as a practical means to achieve all-optical readout of the atomic spectra, from which information on the magnetic field is obtained. During this project, theoretical atomic spectra in strong magnetic fields will be developed, tested and refined. A vapor-cell probe suitable for sensing strong magnetic fields will be designed, fabricated, and tested. Laboratory experiments will be performed to measure the atomic response to magnetic fields in the range of 1 Tesla at ppm sensitivity levels. The method will also be tested in time-varying and switching magnetic fields, on timescales of <100ms. Miniaturization of probes and read-out units will be initiated, leading towards robust and compact, practical sensing elements with higher operation speed and improved performance characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF SBIR Phase I project, Rydberg Technologies Inc. has performed feasibility studies and initial development of an atomic probe technology for sensing and measurement of high magnetic fields.  In the basic method, a circuit-free, atom-based field sensing element is used that provides absolute-standard (atomic) measurements of strong magnetic fields (sub-Gauss to >10 Tesla) with high-speed all-optical readout that is drift-free, re-calibration-free and tolerant against electromagnetic interference.  The unique combination of performance capabilities afforded by the atomic probing method addresses capability gaps in existing high magnetic field measurement technologies and needs in a variety of industries.  This includes the motor monitoring industry, where large generators and motors are susceptible to magnetic over-fluxing that can lead to catastrophic damage, and national user facilities such as the US National High Magnetic Field Laboratory and the US Department of Energy Facility for Rare Ion Beams. These institutes, which are of national importance, require calibration-free high-magnetic-field measurement instrumentation with special capabilities, such as high-speed detection and radiation-hardened sensor heads.

The intellectual merit of the research and development in this Phase I was focused on pilot studies on this type of a novel atomic magnetic-field probe. The overall objective was to establish a first baseline of performance metrics of the new magnetic-field measurement probe technology and to evaluate its ability in addressing needs for improved condition-monitoring and early fault detection in large generators and advanced instrumentation in high magnetic field science and technology.  The effort was comprised of proof-of-principle demonstrations of technology performance capabilities, hardware development, and application demonstrations of the atomic field measurement technology towards these application areas.  

The intellectual merit of the effort included the realization of an operational miniature (millimeter-scale) detector probe and a laser-optics and analysis package for atomic high-magnetic-field measurement and performance evaluation. The targeted milestones were achieved, including the following detailed results. The demonstrated probe performance included the realization of absolute high magnetic field measurements of a ~1 Tesla field with a precision at the sub-100ppm level and measurement acquisition times of 10ms.  Atomic measurements were also performed on weak, AC high-frequency oscillations superimposed onto a large background DC magnetic field, at frequencies of the AC component of up to 1440 Hz.  Directional changes of external magnetic fields were also detected, with demonstrated >1kHz readout bandwidths and multi-axis measurement using a single, miniature atomic probe.  A technology application in condition-monitoring of large rotating generators was performed on a simulation setup that was specifically developed for this Phase I. The simulation task included the real-time monitoring of large, time-varying magnetic fields using the single, multi-axis atomic vapor-cell probe platform.  This provided a proof-of-principle demonstration for a solution to generator over-fluxing and magnetic flux monitoring using a non-contact, multi-axis miniature probe.  Design and characterization of hardware for a portable prototype atomic probe device was initiated.

The results are expected to have a broader impact in the motor and generator monitoring industry, where over-fluxing can cause major damage and downtime that can result in multi-million dollar revenue losses per event. The atomic magnetic-field sensor technology addresses this issue as it affords direct and early detection of over-fluxing conditions to provide users enough time to take measures before damage occurs. Another broader impact of national significance relies in the development of radiation-hardened sensors. The atomic sensor is ideal for this purpose because it provides the required advanced measurement capability and requires only a few selected materials in the construction of wire- and electronics-free detectors.
